etymologies: Middle English (first recorded as a noun in the sense ‘path that someone or something takes’): from Old French trace (noun), tracier (verb), based on Latin tractus (see tract)

examples.text: police are trying to trace a white van seen in the area

definitions: find or describe the origin or development of

examples.text: Bob's book traces his flying career with the Marines

shortDefinitions: find or describe origin or development of

definitions: follow or mark the course or position of (something) with one's eye, mind, or finger

examples.text: through the binoculars, I traced the path I had taken the night before

shortDefinitions: follow or mark course or position of something with one's eye or finger

examples.text: a tear traced a lonely path down her cheek

definitions: copy (a drawing, map, or design) by drawing over its lines on a superimposed piece of transparent paper

examples.text: trace a map of the world onto a large piece of paper

shortDefinitions: copy drawing, map, or design by drawing over its lines on superimposed piece of transparent paper

definitions: draw (a pattern or line), especially with one's finger or toe

examples.text: she traced a pattern in the dirt with the toe of her shoe
the article traces out some of the connections between education, qualifications, and the labor market

definitions: a mark, object, or other indication of the existence or passing of something

examples.text: remove all traces of the old adhesive

shortDefinitions: mark, object, or other indication of existence

definitions: a line or pattern displayed by an instrument using a moving pen or a luminous spot on a screen to show the existence or nature of something that is being investigated.
shortDefinitions: line or pattern displayed by instrument to show existence or nature of something which is being recorded or measured

definitions: a physical change in the brain presumed to be caused by a process of learning or memory.
shortDefinitions: physical change in brain presumed to be caused by process of learning or memory

definitions: a very small quantity, especially one too small to be accurately measured

examples.text: his body contained traces of amphetamines

definitions: a slight indication or barely discernible hint of something

examples.text: just a trace of a smile

definitions: a procedure to investigate the source of something, such as the place from which a telephone call was made, or the origin of an error in a computer program

examples.text: we've got a trace on the call

shortDefinitions: procedure to investigate source of something, such as place from which telephone call was made

definitions: a line which represents the projection of a curve or surface on a plane or the intersection of a curve or surface with a plane.
shortDefinitions: line which represents projection of curve or surface on plane

definitions: a beaten path or small road; a track.
the sum of the elements in the principle diagonal of a square matrix.
shortDefinitions: sum of elements in principal diagonal of square matrix

etymologies: Middle English (denoting a pair of traces): from Old French trais, plural of trait (see trait)

definitions: each of the two side straps, chains, or ropes by which a horse is attached to a vehicle that it is pulling.
shortDefinitions: each of two side straps, chains, or ropes
